study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a tool (TWIST) to predict whether and when stroke patients would regain independent walking within the first 6 months post-stroke.
results_summary: The TWIST tool, combining age, knee extension strength, and Berg Balance Test scores, accurately predicted the probability of achieving independent walking by specific time points (4, 6, 9, 16, or 26 weeks post-stroke) with at least 83% accuracy.
population_specificity: Adults with stroke who had new lower limb weakness and were unable to walk independently (median age 71 years, 36 women).
study_duration: Assessments were completed one week post-stroke, with follow-up for up to 26 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cognitive and motor dual task walking training on dual task walking performance and brain changes in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Both cognitive dual task training (CDTT) and motor dual task training (MDTT) improved dual task walking performance and induced activation changes in specific brain areas, with significantly better outcomes than conventional physical therapy (CPT). The improvements were maintained at a 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 24 sessions of 45-minute training (CDTT, MDTT, or CPT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of moderate versus vigorous walking exercise, as per WHO guidelines, in alleviating depression in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study preliminarily compared 150 minutes of moderate walking and 75 minutes of vigorous walking weekly, assessing depression severity, anxiety, sleep quality, quality of life, and cardiorespiratory fitness. Thirty participants completed the study, but specific outcome results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of moderate walking or 75 minutes of vigorous walking weekly, three times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different classifications of congenital quadriceps abnormalities at birth influence management decisions and walking outcomes.
results_summary: Most patients achieved unaided walking after tailored surgical or non-surgical treatments, though some had persistent knee extension lag. Patients with continuous or discontinuous hypoplasia generally had better outcomes than those with complete aplasia, who required knee arthrodesis.
population_specificity: 15 patients (19 knees) with congenital absence of the quadriceps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of pulmonary hypertension (PH) and exercise pulmonary hypertension (ePH) in functionally limited patients with interstitial fibrosing lung disease (IFLD) and examine correlations between invasive and non-invasive exercise variables.
results_summary: The study found that both PH and ePH were highly prevalent in IFLD patients, with 25% having post-capillary PH, 37.5% pre-capillary PH, and 27.5% ePH. Diffusion capacity markers (DLCO, KCO, FVC%/DLCO%) were lower in ePH and PH groups, and resting cardiac output and pulmonary vascular compliance were impaired in these groups.
population_specificity: 40 functionally limited patients with interstitial fibrosing lung disease (IFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe gait adaptations to irregular surfaces in individuals with cerebral palsy (CP) and compare these adaptations to those of healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with CP exhibit different gait adaptations on irregular surfaces compared to flat surfaces and across CP subtypes, with both typical and pathology-specific adaptations relative to healthy individuals. The review also highlighted the need for more ecologically valid data collection approaches in future studies.
population_specificity: 152 individuals with CP (117 with diplegia, 35 with hemiplegia) and 159 healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nutrition, sleep, and physical activity program, including walking, on health outcomes in overweight airline pilots.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in weekly walking (p = 0.163) despite significant improvements in other physical and mental health outcomes. Walking was not a primary focus, and its efficacy was not strongly demonstrated.
population_specificity: Overweight airline pilots (n = 125)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether street-level built environment interventions could improve children's health in high-income countries, focusing on physical activity or play as the primary health outcome.
results_summary: The review found limited evidence that closing streets to traffic increased activity or play, inconclusive evidence for street design changes and gamifying active travel, and noted poor intervention descriptions and inadequate study designs hampered conclusions.
population_specificity: Children in high-income countries, particularly in deprived neighborhoods.
study_duration: Varied (temporary changes like street closures vs. permanent street design changes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of exercise-based rehabilitation interventions, including walking, for improving symptoms and disability in individuals with post-acute COVID-19 syndrome (PACS).
results_summary: Rehabilitation interventions, including walking, improved dyspnea, anxiety, kinesiophobia, muscle strength, walking capacity, sit-to-stand performance, and quality of life in PACS patients, though pulmonary function results were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Individuals with post-acute COVID-19 syndrome (PACS), aged 49.2-69.4 years, 65% males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review findings on proteoglycan 4 in the context of osteoarthritis (OA) treatment and the challenges of cartilage repair.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the limitations of current OA treatments, such as symptom alleviation without cartilage repair, and emphasizes the need for effective drugs and regenerative therapies. It does not directly discuss walking's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis, particularly those experiencing joint degeneration and cartilage damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an mHealth intervention (SMS prompts with or without a dog pedometer) could increase dog-facilitated physical activity (family dog walking and active play) in children.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant effect on family dog walking and dog play at 1-month, but SMS-only and all intervention children were more likely to increase total dog-facilitated physical activity at 3-months. However, these associations disappeared after adjusting for socio-demographic factors.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-10 years with a family dog in Perth, Western Australia.
effective_dosage: 4 weeks of SMS messages (with or without a dog pedometer and steps diary).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 1- and 3-months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of cardiac rehabilitation (including walking) on microRNA-423-5p levels and cardiac function in hypertensive patients with heart failure and a moderately reduced ejection fraction.
results_summary: The cardiac rehabilitation group showed significantly improved cardiac function (measured by NYHA classification, 6-minute walking test, and echocardiography) and lower microRNA-423-5p expression compared to the control group, suggesting walking as part of rehabilitation was effective. MicroRNA-423-5p demonstrated better diagnostic specificity and accuracy than N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients with heart failure and a moderately reduced ejection fraction (60 patients) and hypertensive patients without heart failure (30 patients as negative controls).
effective_dosage: Not specified (cardiac rehabilitation included walking but details on frequency/intensity were not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a walking-specific functional resistance training (FRT) program improves knee strength in individuals after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: The BRACE group showed greater knee extensor and flexor strength compared to the TARGET MATCH group at both post-intervention and 8-week follow-up, and greater knee flexor strength than the BAND group post-intervention. FRT with a customized knee brace was concluded to be beneficial for ACL rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals after ACL reconstruction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate lead pulling in pet dogs as a welfare concern and its implications for veterinary professionals and dog owners.
results_summary: The study found that lead pulling negatively affects walk quality, frequency, and duration, potentially leading to weight gain and other undesirable behaviors. It also highlighted that aversive equipment and punitive training methods can cause pain, distress, and aggression, weakening dog-owner attachment and increasing relinquishment risk.
population_specificity: Pet dogs and their owners, with a focus on veterinary professionals as advisors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether behavior change techniques using smartphone-linked walking tools could prevent dementia in older adults.
results_summary: The study protocol suggests potential benefits of smartphone-linked Nordic walking with cognitive tasks for dementia prevention, but final efficacy results are pending after the 30-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 60+ in Japan (n=3,498).
effective_dosage: 60-minute group walking sessions twice weekly with cognitive tasks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reach and representativeness of a digital fall prevention intervention (Safe Step) among older adults.
results_summary: The study found a recruitment rate of 4.7%, with participants primarily being highly educated women who frequently used digital technologies. The intervention attracted a specific demographic, suggesting a need for diverse intervention types to reach a broader population.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70 years or older who had experienced a fall or decline in balance in the past year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a moderate-intensity motor skill training (MST) circuit improved walking function in persons with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (PwMISCI) and whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) enhanced these effects.
results_summary: The MST circuit significantly improved walking speed, distance, cadence, and stride length but did not affect interlimb symmetry. No significant differences were observed between groups receiving active or sham tDCS, though walking speed changes approached clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic, motor-incomplete spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Not specified (3-day intervention with MST circuit and concurrent tDCS/sham tDCS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy and safety of Pronolis®HD mono 2.5%, a high-density hyaluronic acid gel, for pain reduction and symptom relief in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain, stiffness, and functional impairment, with 66% of patients achieving >50% pain improvement by 24 weeks. Rescue medication use decreased, and only mild local adverse events (1.6%) were reported.
population_specificity: 166 patients with symptomatic primary knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Single intra-articular injection of 2.5% hyaluronic acid (120 mg in 4.8 mL solution).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a stakeholder-informed robotic gait training (RGT) program to usual care gait training (UC) for improving gait function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study will assess gait function, speed, independence, pain, fatigue, spasm frequency, mental health, and quality of life, comparing RGT using the Ekso exoskeleton to UC methods like overground gait training and body weight-supported treadmill training. Results will be analyzed at admission and discharge to determine differences between groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury admitted to an inpatient rehabilitation facility.
study_duration: Duration of inpatient rehabilitation (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of low-intensity pulsed ultrasound (LIPUS) on pain relief and functional recovery in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LIPUS significantly improved pain relief (measured by VAS score) and functional knee recovery in KOA patients compared to controls. The study concluded that LIPUS could be an alternative therapy for KOA rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (807 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: To test whether cerebellar transcranial direct current stimulation (ctDCS) combined with motor training improves mobility and balance in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Both real- and sham-ctDCS groups showed improved walking performance, balance, and quality of life post-treatment, with effects maintained at follow-up. Real-ctDCS showed a significant interaction effect for motor aspects of quality of life but did not boost motor training effects overall.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (16 subjects).
effective_dosage: Daily ctDCS (real or sham) combined with task-oriented training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of wearable exoskeletons on post-stroke walking, comparing exoskeleton-assisted training with conventional gait training.
results_summary: Exoskeleton-assisted training was superior to conventional gait training in improving walking speed, balance, overall mobility capacity, and endurance, particularly in chronic stroke patients. No studies were available to assess the effect of simply wearing an exoskeleton during walking.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients, including a subgroup with chronic stroke (>6 months post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of passive biaxial ankle movement training synchronized with electrical stimulation therapy (AMT-EST) on ankle proprioception, range of motion, strength, balance, and gait in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in ankle dorsiflexor strength, passive range of motion during foot supination and pronation, and clinical assessments of motor, balance, and gait-related functions. Ankle proprioception was not significantly improved but was predicted by the Fugl-Meyer Assessment score and time since stroke.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=35)
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but 20 sessions were administered

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects and safety of exergaming and conventional rehabilitation on walking ability in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) during corticosteroid treatment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking ability (measured by the MS Walking Scale-12 and Timed 25 Foot Walk) from baseline to follow-up in both exergaming and conventional rehabilitation groups.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) during corticosteroid treatment.
study_duration: Measurements were taken at baseline (T1), immediately after discharge (T2), and 1 month after discharge (T3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intradialytic exercise, including aerobic and resistance training, could prevent declines in nutritional status and physical function in older hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The exercise group showed no significant reductions in handgrip strength, 10-m walking speed, serum albumin, or GNRI, unlike the control group. However, no significant differences were observed in frailty or mobility between groups.
population_specificity: Older hemodialysis patients aged ≥70 years with geriatric issues.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of aerobic exercise using a cycle ergometer and resistance training (four exercises with an elastic tube) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the frequency and timing of loss of ambulation (LOA) in patients with different subtypes of autosomal recessive limb girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMDR) based on age at disease onset.
results_summary: The study found that early childhood-onset LGMDR, particularly subtypes LGMDR9 and LGMDR3-6, progressed to LOA faster than late childhood- or adult-onset cases. The mean time to LOA varied by subtype, with LGMDR9 and LGMDR3-6 showing the shortest progression times.
population_specificity: Patients with autosomal recessive limb girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMDR), categorized by age at onset (adult, late childhood, early childhood) and subtype (LGMDR1, LGMDR2/MM, LGMDR3-6, LGMDR9, LGMDR12).

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of physiotherapy approaches, including weight-supported walking, in treating lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and compare their delivery characteristics.
results_summary: Three weeks of weight-supported walking improved pain and disability in LSS patients, though the evidence was rated as very low. Six weeks of cycling reduced disability compared to weight-supported walking, with low evidence supporting this finding.
population_specificity: Patients with clinical diagnosis of LSS confirmed through imaging techniques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking training (WT) and arm-crank exercise training (ACT) on cardiovascular function, functional capacity, cognition, and quality of life in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study protocol describes a comparison between WT, ACT, and a control group, but results are not yet available as this is a study protocol. The expected outcomes include potential cardiovascular benefits from ACT in symptomatic PAD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: 2 sessions/week, 15 to 10 sets of 2 to 5 minutes at values of 13 to 15 on the Borg scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) related to COVID-19 versus non-COVID-19 GBS, focusing on functional recovery, including walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that 55.55% of GBS patients regained autonomous walking after a mean follow-up of 10.11 months. COVID-19-related GBS appeared to have better clinical outcomes and fewer complications compared to non-COVID-19 GBS.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to inpatient rehabilitation for GBS, including those with and without COVID-19-related GBS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a self-managed cooling intervention on pain reduction and physical activity improvement, including walking, in individuals with recently healed venous leg ulcers (VLUs) and diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: The study found minimal reductions in pain and slight improvements in physical activity, including walking time, but the outcomes were not statistically significant. Walking time improved more notably in the VLU groups compared to the DFU groups.
population_specificity: 140 individuals with previously healed VLUs and DFUs receiving care in outpatient wound centers in the Southeastern U.S.
effective_dosage: Cooling or placebo patch application for 30 minutes, 3 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate bone mineral density changes in three fixation zones and the biomechanical effects of 3D-printed titanium porous metaphyseal cones in revision knee replacement patients.
results_summary: The study found bone loss (-0.086 ± 0.05 g/cm) and utilized DXA, CT, and patient-specific FE modeling to assess biomechanical effects at 6 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing revision knee replacement.
study_duration: 1 year (for BMD changes), 6 months (for biomechanical effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait retraining strategies and tools improve gait biomechanics and symptoms in individuals with hip or knee osteoarthritis compared to control or alternate interventions.
results_summary: Gait retraining with real-time biofeedback showed strong evidence for improving walking biomechanics, while kinesiology taping had moderate evidence for pain relief. Other interventions had conflicting or limited evidence of benefit.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip or knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 6-month home-based coaching program, including physical activity, on heart rate variability and functional outcomes in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The coaching program significantly improved walking distance in the experimental group but had no effect on heart rate variability or other functional measures. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients
effective_dosage: Not specified (coaching program included physical activity, home visits, and weekly phone calls)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nonoperative treatments (including activity modification like reducing walking) and surgical interventions for lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The study found that nonoperative treatments, including reducing walking, led to symptom improvement in about one-third of patients, no change in 50%, and worsening in 10-20%. Surgical interventions showed better symptom relief compared to nonoperative therapy in selected patients.
population_specificity: Older adults with lumbar spinal stenosis, particularly those with back, buttock, and lower extremity pain.
study_duration: Up to 3 years for nonoperative follow-up; trial durations varied for surgical interventions.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the developmental outcomes, including independent walking, in patients with CDKL5 deficiency disorder (CDD).
results_summary: The study found that only a quarter of girls and a smaller proportion of boys with CDD achieve independent walking, indicating severe developmental impairment. Clinical variability in walking ability is likely genetically determined.
population_specificity: Patients with CDKL5 deficiency disorder (CDD), primarily infants and children with early-onset seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using intraoperative pressure sensors to achieve soft-tissue balance during total knee arthroplasty (TKA) improved clinical outcomes compared to manual balancing.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in clinical or functional outcomes two years after TKA between sensor-guided balancing and manual balancing, despite improved quantitative soft-tissue balance with sensors.
population_specificity: 250 patients (285 TKAs) undergoing total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antinociceptive efficacy of the preoperative PENG block, residual motor block, and time for postoperative functional recovery in patients with hip fracture.
results_summary: The PENG block provided effective analgesia, reducing pain by at least 3 points on the VNS at all evaluation points, with an average difference of 7.5 points. It enabled safe patient transfer and placement without complications and promoted early mobility and rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty for hip fracture.
study_duration: Preoperative block with assessments up to 24 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if multimodal neuroimaging features, alone or combined with psychosocial and health measures, could predict adherence to a 6-month exercise intervention in older adults.
results_summary: Higher cortical thickness in specific brain regions and functional connectivity in certain networks predicted better exercise adherence. A combined multimodal model achieved the highest predictive strength for adherence.
population_specificity: 131 older adults (mean age 65.79 ± 4.65 years, 63% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pulmonary rehabilitation (which includes walking) for improving exercise tolerance and quality of life in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
results_summary: Pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, reduced respiratory questionnaire scores, and enhanced lung function metrics like forced vital capacity and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. The quality of evidence ranged from low to moderate.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (549 participants across 11 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Alemtuzumab treatment on physiological, physical, and cognitive function, including walking performance, in persons with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (pwMS) over two years.
results_summary: The study found improvements in short-distance walking (T25FWT, SSST) and cognitive function (SDMT, SRT) at 24 months, while the primary outcome (6MWT) and other measures remained stable.
population_specificity: Relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis patients (n=17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of electromechanical-assisted gait training versus conventional gait training on clinical walking function and gait symmetry in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both electromechanical-assisted and conventional gait training improved functional ambulatory category (FAC) and clinical walking functions, but gait symmetry improvements were limited. Subacute stroke patients showed more significant improvements in walking function than chronic patients, but gait asymmetry did not improve in either group.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=144), including subacute and chronic subgroups.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking improves pain-free walking distance, functional status, quality of life, and Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) in patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study found that walking increased pain-free walking distance and improved functional status, quality of life, and ABI in PAD patients with IC. Secondary outcomes included improved cardiorespiratory and muscle fitness, with effects maintained at 6 and 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic PAD (intermittent claudication) from 15 primary healthcare centers in North Barcelona, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ground-based walking training on exercise capacity, physical activity, quadriceps muscle strength, and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension.
results_summary: The walking group showed significant improvements in endurance capacity, maximal exercise capacity, and step count, but no significant changes were observed in 6-minute walk distance, physical activity, quadriceps muscle strength, or quality of life compared to the control group. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension (n=24).
effective_dosage: 30-minute supervised walking 2 days/week plus unsupervised walking at least 1 day/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the SPACE FOR COPD programme (a home-based self-management intervention involving walking) on exercise tolerance and mental well-being compared to usual care in COPD patients post-pulmonary rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study assessed endurance capacity, maximal exercise capacity, health-related quality of life, mood, and other outcomes at 6 and 12 months, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The intervention included motivational interviewing and group sessions over 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with a clinical diagnosis of COPD who had completed pulmonary rehabilitation within the past 4 weeks.
effective_dosage: Home-based manual and 4 group sessions (2 hours each) over 12 months.

study_goal: To assess the safety and efficacy of ultrasound-guided erector spinae plane block (ESPB) for perioperative analgesia in posterior cervical spine surgery (PCSS).
results_summary: ESPB significantly reduced intraoperative opioid consumption, muscle relaxant usage, surgical duration, and blood loss compared to standard multimodal analgesia. Postoperative pain scores, alertness, satisfaction, and time to mobilization were also significantly better in the ESPB group.
population_specificity: Eighty-six patients requiring sub-axial PCSS with or without instrumentation.
effective_dosage: 15 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine and 8 mg Dexamethasone bilaterally.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of local vibration applied to the plantar region of the foot on static and dynamic balance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Participants receiving plantar vibration showed greater improvements in static and dynamic balance assessments compared to the control group, with significant improvements in Overall Stability Index, fall risk, and Timed Up and Go Test times.
population_specificity: Thirty inpatient stroke patients.
effective_dosage: Local vibration therapy at 80Hz frequency alongside conventional physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a moderate-intensity physical activity program on body composition, muscle strength, and balance in elderly females to assess sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in body composition (reduced BMI, body fat percentage, and fat mass; increased basal metabolic rate and skeletal muscle mass), upper and lower extremity muscle strength, and balance. The program also enhanced handgrip strength and gait speed, effectively evaluating sarcopenia.
population_specificity: 30 healthy elderly females
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity physical activity program twice a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical strength of two percutaneous Achilles tendon repair techniques (knotless suture anchor repair and percutaneous end-to-end repair) during simulated progressive rehabilitation involving walking.
results_summary: Both repair techniques showed no significant difference in clinical failure rates, gap displacement, or overall failure during simulated walking conditions. All repairs eventually failed during the ambulation phase, with different failure modes observed between the two techniques.
population_specificity: Fresh-frozen below-knee cadaveric extremities (9 matched pairs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether customised preformed foot orthoses (FOs) could improve gait parameters, such as peak pressure and pressure time integrals, in children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
results_summary: Customised preformed FOs significantly reduced peak pressures and pressure time integrals in the heel, forefoot, and 5th metatarsophalangeal joint compared to a control device, with statistically significant improvements observed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. The intervention was safe, well-accepted, and associated with a high retention rate (92%).
population_specificity: Children aged 5-18 with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and lower limb symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (customised chair-side low-density full-length Slimflex Simple device).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) syndrome differentiation in improving exercise endurance and quality of life in patients with pneumoconiosis.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvements in six-minute walking distance (6MWD), St. George Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) score, mMRC score, CAT score, and total symptom score compared to the control group, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 96 patients with pneumoconiosis (83 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on water-based therapeutic exercise (WBTE) for stroke survivors, describe intervention content, summarize effects, and identify gaps in research.
results_summary: The review found that WBTE had a strong effect on balance and gait-related outcomes in 80% of controlled and comparison trials, suggesting beneficial impacts for stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors (18+ years) of any stroke type (ischemic/hemorrhagic) or stage (acute/chronic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a balance-focused multimodal exercise intervention, including walking, improves balance and reduces falls for people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study evaluates the effects of a 6-month multimodal exercise intervention (including walking) on balance and fall rates in people with MCI, with results pending as the abstract does not report final outcomes.
population_specificity: People with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) living in the community.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking program details not provided).
study_duration: 6-month intervention period with 6-month maintenance follow-up (total 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mobile health tool (WalkingPad app) with a built-in virtual assistant could improve motivation, behavior change, and adherence to home-based exercise therapy in patients with peripheral arterial disease and intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found that the WalkingPad app, especially with a virtual assistant, was expected to improve walking distances (maximal and pain-free), quality of life, and walking speed in patients with PAD. The virtual assistant was hypothesized to enhance motivation and adherence to exercise.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (IC) recruited from an Angiology and Vascular Surgery Department in Portugal.

study_goal: To compare the effects of exergaming versus conventional exercises on cognition, lower-limb functional coordination, and stepping time in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Exergaming showed more improvements in complex attention, executive function, and lower-limb functional coordination in the short-term compared to conventional exercises. In the mid-term, exergaming was more effective for improving stepping time and lower-limb coordination, but neither approach was superior for simple attention and reaction time.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: To determine the feasibility and potential efficacy of early, intensive, play-based lower extremity therapy (ELEVATE) on gross motor function in young children with perinatal stroke.
results_summary: The intervention improved gross motor function (GMFM-66) more in the Immediate Group than the Delay Group, with greater benefits in younger children. Step counts increased significantly, and parent-trained children also showed improvement, though with more variability.
population_specificity: Children aged 8 months to 3 years with MRI-confirmed perinatal ischemic stroke and early signs of hemiparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of outdoor community ambulation interventions in improving walking endurance, depression, and other health outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant difference in walking endurance and depression outcomes between outdoor community ambulation and comparison interventions. Some studies suggested possible improvements in gait speed and lower extremity function, but most evidence was of low to very low certainty.
population_specificity: Older adults (specific age range not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical characteristics, management, and challenges of progressive-fibrosing interstitial lung disease (PF-ILD), including the use of multi-dimensional approaches like the 6-min walking test.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results related to walking; it focuses on the broader management of ILD, including diagnostic and treatment strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with interstitial lung diseases (ILD), including connective-tissue disease-associated ILD, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and sarcoidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-intensity or medium-intensity brisk walking improves early attendance, adherence, and physical outcomes in cardiac rehabilitation patients post-percutaneous coronary intervention.
results_summary: The study compared low-intensity and medium-intensity brisk walking for improving adherence and cardiopulmonary endurance, with primary outcomes measured via oxygen consumption (VO₂) changes, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-intensity vs. medium-intensity brisk walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether echocardiographic variables, including right ventricle diastolic diameter (RVDD), could predict unfavorable COPD progression, including functional capacity measured by the 6-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: Patients with RVDD greater than 35 mm showed worse functional capacity in the 6MWT and more frequent disease exacerbations. RVDD was correlated with reduced forced vital capacity and walking distance, accounting for 55% of the variation in 6MWT distance.
population_specificity: 91 patients diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Qingjin Yiqi granules (QJYQ) combined with standard rehabilitation treatments (SRTs) for improving breathlessness, fatigue, and walking distance in post-COVID-19 condition (PCC) patients.
results_summary: QJYQ combined with SRTs improved breathlessness (mMRC scale) and fatigue (Borg scale) compared to SRTs alone, but no significant difference was observed in symptoms score or 6-minute walking distance (6MWD). No treatment-related adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 388 patients with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to gather developmental and clinical information on a large number of patients with MEF2C-related disorders, including limited walking abilities.
results_summary: The study identified prominent features of MEF2C-related disorders, including limited walking (implied by developmental delay), but did not specifically evaluate the efficacy or safety of walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with MEF2C-related disorders (developmental and cognitive delay, limited walking, hypotonia, and seizures).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of a home-based, walking exercise behavior change intervention delivered by physical therapists in adults with PAD and intermittent claudication compared with usual care.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a statistically significant improvement in 6-minute walking distance (16.7 m difference) at 3 months compared to usual care. Secondary outcomes, including WELCH scores and illness perception, also improved significantly in the intervention group, though 5 of 8 secondary outcomes were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (mean age 68 years, 30% women, 79% White race).
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention, not a fixed dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a literacy-focused program and an exercise program in preventing physical frailty and improving well-being in older adults.
results_summary: Both programs showed significant improvements in subjective well-being, occupational performance, and physical fitness, with the exercise group demonstrating higher quality of life and physical fitness outcomes compared to the literacy group.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65 to 85 in Ward A, Tokyo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of moderate-intensity aerobic training (including walking) on telomere length, functional capacity, and other physiological outcomes in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study expects positive outcomes for telomere length and functional capacity in the aerobic training group, suggesting that aerobic exercise like walking may delay biological aging and improve physiological markers in HFrEF patients.
population_specificity: Men and women aged 50–80 years with HFrEF.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic training (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify whether SID142 (a controlled-release tablet of cilostazol and Ginkgo biloba leaf extract) was noninferior to Renexin (a combination pill of the same ingredients) in improving ischemic symptoms in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: SID142 was found to be noninferior to Renexin in reducing lower extremity pain and showed no significant differences in secondary efficacy endpoints. Additionally, SID142 had a significantly lower incidence of adverse reactions compared to Renexin.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: SID142 (200 mg cilostazol + 160 mg Ginkgo biloba leaf extract) once daily; Renexin (dosage not specified) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence on the benefits of robot-assisted gait training compared to conventional rehabilitation for improving gait in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that robotic devices were not superior to conventional interventions for improving gait speed in MS patients, and the methodological quality of the reviewed studies was moderate-low. Robot-assisted gait training was considered equally effective as conventional rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on pediatric foot and ankle pathologies, including clubfoot, congenital vertical talus, toe walking, and others, to highlight current best practices and treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study reviewed 73 papers, focusing on new findings and significant contributions in treating various pediatric foot and ankle conditions, with the goal of improving understanding and current practices.
population_specificity: Children with foot and ankle pathologies (e.g., clubfoot, congenital vertical talus, toe walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of warm acupuncture combined with meloxicam and comprehensive nursing on pain improvement and joint function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The combined treatment group showed greater improvements in pain, mobility, stability, walking ability, and ability to walk up and down stairs compared to the control and traditional Chinese medicine groups. The treatment also reduced inflammatory mediators and oxidative stress markers more effectively.
population_specificity: 81 patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; meloxicam dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 13-week integrative neuromuscular training program could improve gait spatiotemporal and kinematic parameters in children with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The exercise group maintained baseline stance and single-limb support times and maximum foot abduction angle during walking, while the control group showed increases in these parameters. The exercise group also maintained pelvic tilt and ankle abduction angles, whereas the control group exhibited increased pelvic anterior tilt and ankle abduction angles.
population_specificity: Children (10.77 ± 1.24 years, 31 girls) with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program based on fundamental movement skills, strength activities, and aerobic training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and retention effects of auditory biofeedback gait training on biomechanics and talar cartilage characteristics in patients with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: The AudFB group showed significant reductions in lateral foot pressure and force, along with a medial shift in center of pressure, both immediately and 1-week post-intervention. No changes were observed in the Control group or in ultrasound measures of talar cartilage for either group.
population_specificity: 18 participants with chronic ankle instability (CAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether intensive exercise (walking) reduces the 1-year in-stent restenosis rate in patients with femoropopliteal lesions after endovascular therapy.
results_summary: Intensive exercise significantly improved the patency rate of bare nitinol stents at 12 months, with 81.3% freedom from in-stent restenosis in the intensive group compared to 47.6% in the non-intensive group. No stent fractures were observed in the intensive exercise group.
population_specificity: Patients with claudication and de novo stenosis or occlusion of the femoropopliteal artery.
effective_dosage: Intensive exercise (walking for ≥30 minutes per session, ≥3 times per week).
